headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Lowe's Companies' Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] .Also, supplemental reference slides are available on Lowe's' Investor Relations website within t
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Lowe's Companies' Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] .
Also, supplemental reference slides are available on Lowe's' Investor Relations website within the investor packet. While management will not be speaking directly to the slides, these slides are meant to facilitate your review of the company's results and to be used as a reference to document following the call. 
During this call, management will be using certain non-GAAP financial measures. The supplemental reference slides include information about these measures and a reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures. 
Statements made during this call will include forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Management's expectations and opinions reflected in those statements are subject to risks, and the company can give no assurance that they will prove to be correct. These risks are described in the company's earnings release and in its filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Hosting today's conference will be Mr. Robert Niblock, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mr. Rick, Chief Operating Officer; and Mr. Bob Hull, Chief Financial Officer. 
I'll now turn the program over to Mr. Niblock for opening remarks. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks again from Lowe's. I'm pleased that we delivered another strong quarter, with comparable sales growth of 7.3%. Comp growth was driven by a 4.9% increase in comp average ticket and a 2.3% increase in comp transactions. The mix of c
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks again from Lowe's. I'm pleased that we delivered another strong quarter, with comparable sales growth of 7.3%. Comp growth was driven by a 4.9% increase in comp average ticket and a 2.3% increase in comp transactions. The mix of comp ticket and comp transactions was consistent with our expectations. 
Comparable sales growth for our U.S. business was 7.4% for the quarter. We saw balanced performance across the country again this quarter, with all 3 divisions, the North, South and West, generating comps within a tight range. In fact, all 14 regions had comps greater than 5%. 
Likewise, we reported positive comps in all 12 product categories, and our Pro Services business continued its strong performance, with comp sales in line with company average during the quarter. 
I'm also pleased to share that our team in Canada delivered double-digit comps in local currency for the seventh consecutive quarter. 
We remain focused on improving our profitability even while investing in key capabilities to drive sales growth. For the quarter, we drove 115 basis points of operating margin expansion and earnings per share of $0.46, a 59% increase over last year's fourth quarter. 
For the year, we delivered comparable sales growth of 4.3% and earnings per share of $2.71, a 27% increase over fiscal 2013. 
Delivering on our commitment to return excess cash to shareholders, in the quarter, we repurchased $1 billion of stock under our share repurchase program and paid $225 million in dividends. For the year, we repurchased $3.9 billion of stock and paid $822 million in dividends. 
As we head into fiscal 2015, microeconomic fundamentals are aligned for modestly stronger home improvement industry growth. Jobs, incomes, household financial conditions are expected to continue strengthening in 2015, building on the momentum gained in 2014. 
Coupled with an increase in revolving credit usage, these trends set the stage for higher discretionary consumer spending, and the sharp decline in energy prices should allow consumers to pump less money into their tanks and more into home improvement and other forms of discretionary spending. 
Improvements in housing should persist in 2015 as well. Strong income gains, mortgage rates that remain historically low and moderating home price growth should keep home affordability at elevated levels and provide more support for home buying 2015. 
Expected growth in the home improvement market is further supported by recent consumer confidence groups [ph] and the results of our fourth quarter consumer sentiment survey, which revealed that homeowners' views around personal finances and home values continue to improve. In fact, approximately 1/2 of homeowners now believe the value of their homes is increasing. 
Along with the positive progression in sentiment, this quarter, even more homeowners indicated their home improvement spending was increased. And while most of the home improvement projects they have planned are still small-ticket, the survey indicated boost in plans for big-ticket projects versus this time last year. 
In 2015, we will continue to focus on a few key priorities to capitalize on opportunities within an improving economy. We'll further pursue top line growth by differentiating ourselves through better customer experiences and improving our product and service offerings for the Pro customer. 
In addition, we continue developing omnichannel capabilities as part of our long-term commitment to meet customers on their terms whenever and wherever they choose to engage with us. 
We also remain committed to improving our productivity and profitability, with opportunities in a few specific areas, including store payroll, marketing and leveraging our scale to get cost savings on indirect spend. These efforts give us confidence in our business outlook for 2015. Bob will share these details in a few minutes. 
But first, I would like to thank our more than 265,000 employees for their hard work and dedication. Their steadfast commitment to serving customers is critical to our success and an important driver of this quarter's strong results. Thanks again for your interest. And with that, let me turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Robert, and good morning, everyone. As Robert stated, we delivered strong performance in the quarter, and I'm pleased to share that our store employees [indiscernible] record pay-up from ourselves and service employee incentive program. This progr
componenttext:
Thanks, Robert, and good morning, everyone. As Robert stated, we delivered strong performance in the quarter, and I'm pleased to share that our store employees [indiscernible] record pay-up from ourselves and service employee incentive program. This program rewards store employees for achieving the sales and profitability targets and for delivering outstanding customer service. 
We continue to capitalize on an improving macro backdrop through our enhanced sales operations planning process, improving relevance with the Pro and expanding customer experience design capabilities. 
In the fourth quarter, we used our enhanced Sales & Operations Planning process to coordinate inventory flows, advertising and training around our celebrated season, winter campaign. With this campaign, we targeted 4 important Southern [ph] locations into our refresh, holiday decorating, gifting and getting organized. For each occasion, our store, logistics, merchandising and marketing teams collaborated to ensure that we had relevant products available to customers at the right time, that they were effectively advertised and strategically promoted to drive traffic and cross merchandise to build the basket. As a result, we drove both online and in-store transactions and ticket growth, and we fulfilled orders in the most convenient manner our customer. Our ability to sell products from a store, online, in-home or through contact centers is a distinct, competitive advantage that allows us to engage customers on their terms whenever and wherever they choose. 
We know that, for many projects, more than half of the customers research online before making an in-store purchase. And for purchases made on Lowe's.com, approximately 60% [ph] are pick up in-store; 10% are delivered from the store; and the remaining 30% are a partial shift. This speaks to our ability to leverage our existing infrastructure with the omnichannel capabilities we are introducing. 
From a category standpoint, we drove above-company average comps in kitchen, appliances, lumber, raw materials, millwork and outdoor power equipment. We drove company average comps in fashion fixtures, tools and hardware. 
Customers are increasingly interested in refreshing the interior and exterior of their homes, so we used targeted promotions, coupled with our investment in project specialists, to drive performance in fashion fixtures, flooring, kitchens, appliances and millwork. We are pleased with the project specialist programs. Currently, we have project specialists who focus on exterior the home of the available across all U.S. stores. 
Our interior project specialists program has an average ticket of about $10,000, and customer satisfaction scores over 15 points higher than the industry standard. So we're expanding it to another 470 stores in 2015, reaching over 3/4 of our stores by year-end. With our ability to ordinate sound, provide design expertise and find the right contract to visit the job, we are rapidly becoming the project authority of home improvement. 
Within lumber and materials, we spent -- we met strong unit demand for dimensional and treated lumber, with robust inventory depth. We also leverage our store's canopy program, and which each market reflects the most relevant lumber build materials to be factor just outside of Pro entrance under the canopy. This program helps Pros quickly find out the lumber, plywood and wildboard, quick out -- quickly check out, receive loading the systems and get back on the job. 
With outdoor power equipment, we met strong Midwest and Northeast demand for snow plowers. 
In tools and hardware, we saw a particular strength in power pneumatic [ph] tools. We had a compelling assortment of national tool brands, and we've expanded our relationship with the [indiscernible] to include  pneumatic tools. Combined with Boston, Lowe's now has the #1 and #2 brands, making us the destination for pneumatic tools, particularly for the Pro. 
Kessler, the innovative leader in [indiscernible] is another important brand for Pro customers. And I'm pleased to announce that we just recently added this leading brand for allowing assortment. The expanded relationship with brands like [indiscernible] and the additions of the brand like Kessler, build on a solid foundation to serve the Pro. 
In fact, 14 consecutive quarters of Pro comps at or above the company average are a testament to this foundation, which includes dedicated service in our stores, inventory depth and our [indiscernible] value proposition. 
Additionally, fuel-based [ph] Pro executives than our national accounts team make it easy for medium to large sized companies and government entities to do business with us. We are also completing our beta test of LowesForPros.com, which has been well-received by our customers. This dedicated platform is fully transactional and will provide Pros usual functionality such as the ability to develop acquisition list and either purchases as well as customized product catalogs. 
This site can also be integrated with purchasing systems among Pros use to manage their business, further streamlining their day-to-day operations and have them working more effectively. 
We have received positive feedback from the flexibility and ease-of-use and expect to make it available to all Pros this spring. 
Last quarter, Mike told you about the holiday decor experience we implemented in all of our stores using the stage created for our outdoor living experience. This stage leverages our largest store format. 
Developed through a collaboration between our merchants, stores and customer experience design team, the holiday decor experience is our customers to decorate, raise their awareness of the breadth of our holiday decor and gift offerings and providing solutions -- project solutions relevant to the holiday micro seasons. The customer response was very positive, and the improved sales, inventory sales group and gross margin for the products included in this set. 
We are now transitioning into this space that our outdoor living experience in preparation for the critical spring selling season. 
In addition to our efforts to drive top line growth, we are focused on driving productivity and profitability. 
During the quarter, our source once again effectively managed payroll hours as comp sales accelerated, increasing sales by our by approximately 5% and driving 28 basis points of payroll expense leverage. 
They drove this leverage while maintaining great customers satisfaction stores and best-in-class inventory spring performance. We are pleased with the progress this year on sales growth, productivity and operating profitability. And we're committed to further improvement in 2015. 
In 2015, we expect to drive sales growth as we further capitalize on the improving macro backdrop through increased relevance with the Pro, improved customer experiences and the continued development of omnichannel capabilities. We will increase gross margin by continuing to partner with our vendors to drive innovation and lower first cost by leveraging our supply chain fixed cost. We will continue to leverage payroll as we further align payroll hours to customer traffic and more efficiently complete noncustomer-facing task. 
Will also drive expense productivity as we increased sales by reducing fixed expenses. For example, we will reduce our total marketing spend even while increasing our presence in targeted media. And we will obtain further expense efficiency by consolidating procurements of [indiscernible] services across our corporate i-store functions. Likewise, we will increase inventory turns approximately 15 basis points, as we continue to hold inventory per-store flat while increasing comp sales. With solid depth of high velocity items and job [indiscernible] in place, we will obtain additional inventory productivity, as we continue to thoughtfully conduct our line review process. 
We are excited about the further improvements we'll make to our business in 2015 and look forward to sharing our progress as the year unfolds. 
Thank you for interest in Lowe's, and I will now turn the call over to Bob.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. And good morning, everyone. Sales for the fourth quarter were $12.5 billion, which represented a 7.6% increase over last year's fourth quarter. Total average ticket increased by 4.9% to $66.17, and total transactions increased 2.5%. Comp s
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. And good morning, everyone. Sales for the fourth quarter were $12.5 billion, which represented a 7.6% increase over last year's fourth quarter. Total average ticket increased by 4.9% to $66.17, and total transactions increased 2.5%. 
Comp sales were 7.3% in the quarter. As you heard from Rick, further momentum from our initiatives and improving execution drove balanced performance in the quarter. 
Comp average ticket increased 4.9%, and comp transactions increased 2.3%. 
Looking at monthly trends. Comps were 6.7% in November, 7.2% in December and 8.2% in January. For the year, total sales were $56.2 billion, an increase of 5.3% [ph], driven by a comp sales increase of 4.3%, a full year sales compared with partial year following the August 2013 acquisition and new stores. 
For 2014, comp average ticket increased 2.4%, and comp transactions increased 1.8%. 
Gross margin for the fourth quarter was 34.6% of sales, which is roughly flat to last year. In the quarter, the mix of products sold negatively impacted gross margin by 25 basis points. 
Also, price actions hurt gross margin by approximately 10 basis points. These items were essentially offset by value improvement and better seasonal to sell-through, which helped by 15 and 10 basis points, respectively. 
For the year, gross margin of 34.79% represented an increase of 20 basis points over 2013. SG&A for Q4 was 25.24% of sales, which leveraged 88 basis points. The SG&A leverage was driven by a variety of factors. In the quarter, store payroll leveraged 28 basis points due to better alignment of hours and customer traffic and strong comp sales. 
Property tax expense leveraged 21 basis points due to favorability in valuations recognized this year. 
At our analyst conference in December, we noted that expense productivity would come from utilizing our scale to reduce the spend on indirect goods and services. In the quarter, these efforts allowed us to leverage telecommunications and car [ph] expenses. Also, given the sales growth, we're able to leverage fixed costs. 
Lastly, we have approximately 30 basis points of expense leverage associated with last year's asset procurement. 
These items were offset somewhat by employee interest deleverage of 30 basis points. Our higher expenses were driven by both higher enrollment as well as cost inflation. 
For the year, SG&A was 23.62% [ph] of sales and leveraged 46 basis points versus 2013. 
Depreciation expense was $362 million for the quarter, which is 2.89% of sales and leveraged 28 basis points. The leverage was driven by higher sales as well as assets becoming fully depreciated. 
Earnings before interest and taxes for the quarter were 6.53% of sales, which represented a 115 basis point increase. 
For the year, EBITDA of 8.53% [ph] represented an increase of 76 basis points over 2013. 
Interest expense at $132 million for the quarter leveraged 5 basis points as a percentage of sales. 
Pretax earnings for the quarter were 5.48% of sales. Effective tax rate for Q4 was 34.5%. The lower rate this quarter, relative to the 38.7% [ph] last year, was driven by tax provisions that had inspired but were retroactively extended by Congress for calendar 2014 in the fourth [ph] quarter. 
The tax rate for the quarter was also lower than our expected 36%, resulting in an EPS benefit of $0.01 per share. 
For the year, the effective tax rate is 36.9% compared to 37.8% for 2013. The lower tax rate for the year was the result of the settlement of prior year tax matters. 
Q4 net earnings of $450 million increased 47% versus last year. Earnings per share of $0.46 for the quarter were up 59% to last year. For 2014, earnings per share of $2.71 were up 27% [ph] versus 2013. 
Earnings per share performance for both the fourth quarter and the year represent record highs for the company. 
Transitioning to the balance sheet. Cash and cash equivalents at the end of the quarter were $466 million. Inventory of $8.9 billion was down $216 million or 2.4% from last year. The decrease was a result of better inventory management and improved sales proceeds from goods. 
Inventory turnover was 3.85, an increase of 11 basis points over last year. 
Asset turnover increased 10 basis points to 1.69. Moving on to liabilities. Accounts payable of $5.1 billion was up $116 million or 2.3% to last year. The increase relates to almost 2-day improvement in days payable outstanding. 
At the end of the fourth quarter, adjusted debt-to-EBITDAR was 2.15 [ph]. Return on invested capital increased 243 basis points to 13.9%. 
Now looking at the statement of cash flows. Cash flow from operations was $4.9 billion, an increase of 20% over last year, due to net earnings growth and working capital. Capital expenditures were $880 million, down 6% from last year. 
Free cash flow of $4 billion represented a 20% increase over 2013. 
During the quarter, we repurchased 14.9 million shares for $1 billion through the open-market. 
For the year, we repurchased almost 74 million shares for a total of $3.9 billion. 
Looking ahead, I'd like to address Lowe's' business outlook. As Robert noted, economic forecasts suggest modestly stronger growth in the home improvement industry in 2015. While we are optimistic about both the macro forecasts and our improving execution, we've taken a prudent approach to our 2015 outlook. 
For the year, we expect total sales increase of approximately 4.5% to 5%, driven by comp sales increase of 4% [indiscernible] 
[Audio Gap] 
2-year comps will improve sequentially through the year. 
We are anticipating an EBIT increase of 80 to 100 basis points. As I noted during our analyst investor conference in December, we are now targeting 25 to 30 basis points of EBIT expansion [indiscernible] above 1%. While this is our expectation for the year, there will be some choppiness quarter-to-quarter. 
For example, let me offer 2 items that will put pressure on the flow-through for the first quarter. In Q1 last year, we had 70 basis points of gross margin expansion, our strongest quarter of the year. This year, we expect gross margin to be flattish in Q1 while improving roughly 20 basis points for the year. 
Also, in Q1 last year, with our lowest comp and, therefore, reduced bonus accruals. This year, we plan to improve a target levels, resulting in deleverage 25 basis points in Q1 while leveraging roughly 10 basis points for the year. 
We expect that most of the EBIT improvement will come from SG&A. Expense leverage will come in store payroll, marketing, bonus and leveraging our scale to achieve cost savings on indirect spend. 
In addition, we expect a fixed cost leverage  associated with sales growth. 
The effective tax rate is expected to be 38.1%. Higher tax rate relative to 2014 is a result of the settlement of prior year tax matters recognized in Q1 2014. 
A higher tax rate impacts earnings by roughly $0.06 per share. 
For the year, we expect earnings per share of approximately $3.29, which represents a 22.5% increase over 2014. We are forecasting cash flows from operations to be approximately $5 billion. 
Our capital plan for 2015 is approximately $1.2 billion. 
This results in estimated free cash flow of $3.8 billion for 2015. 
We expect to issue incremental debt during the year as we manage to the 2.25x lease adjusted debt-to-EBITDAR target. 
With approximately $2.4 billion remaining under share repurchase authorization at the end of the fiscal year, our guidance assumes approximately $3.8 billion of share repurchases for 2015. All future share repurchases authorizations are subject to board approval. 
Regina, we're now ready for questions.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Robert, maybe looking at industry and your performance, kind of from 30,000 feet, it suddenly seems that the microenvironment is improving even if minute housing is okay, but not great. As you look at your business, do think there is less cyclicality and
componenttext: Robert, maybe looking at industry and your performance, kind of from 30,000 feet, it suddenly seems that the microenvironment is improving even if minute housing is okay, but not great. As you look at your business, do think there is less cyclicality and is it left type housing today that it has been in years past?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll talk about this the past, and how really, also the prior cycles, our housing was turned over, it was going up and down. Some values continue to maintain their value actually [indiscernible] increase during a lot of those cycles. But we saw that
componenttext: Well, I'll talk about this the past, and how really, also the prior cycles, our housing was turned over, it was going up and down. Some values continue to maintain their value actually [indiscernible] increase during a lot of those cycles. But we saw that kind of disconnect in this most recent -- this most recent downturn when home prices dropped dramatically. So we're kind of going through this cycle. We're getting home prices starting to come back up. This is driving confidence among homeowners that they can reinvest in their home again. And certainly, there's been a lot of deferred investments that kind of the wish list, the to-do this on their refrigerator. So people are reengaging that, and that's what we saw in our survey, we're resorting to see an increase in those not only taking the discretionary projects on but also starting to move into larger projects. We're getting confidence in the macroenvironment confidence [indiscernible]. But at end of the day, income on housing are continuing to be the things that drive our business. So there was a little bit of a disconnect from the downturn, but we are seeing consumers reengage. We feel good about that [indiscernible] guidance for 2015.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one follow-up, if I may. With respect to foreign currency effects, what were the effects on your '14 numbers in aggregate? And what impact do you have built in your 2015 guidance as a result of the strengthening dollar?
componenttext: Okay. And one follow-up, if I may. With respect to foreign currency effects, what were the effects on your '14 numbers in aggregate? And what impact do you have built in your 2015 guidance as a result of the strengthening dollar?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Alan, the impact was essentially nominal to us. Our international business -- kind of Mexico relatively small pieces of our portfolio businesses. We did have a modest drag on comps, 10-or-so basis points for the quarter and about the same for the year.
componenttext: So Alan, the impact was essentially nominal to us. Our international business -- kind of Mexico relatively small pieces of our portfolio businesses. We did have a modest drag on comps, 10-or-so basis points for the quarter and about the same for the year. As we think about FX going into '15, this one model roughly the same levels as where we are today.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttextpreview: Just minor points, but just a clarify. Investor Day, I think you mentioned margins with at least 9.5% in 2015. I think the guidance range for 2015 now, if our math is right on GAAP EBIT, is around 9.3% to 9.5%. Is that the right interpretation? And if so,
componenttext: Just minor points, but just a clarify. Investor Day, I think you mentioned margins with at least 9.5% in 2015. I think the guidance range for 2015 now, if our math is right on GAAP EBIT, is around 9.3% to 9.5%. Is that the right interpretation? And if so, is the range -- I guess -- the wider range, is that just conservatism? Or is something changed in hundred looking at things next year?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: So what I would say is that, when we put our outlook for the year, this is something that we expect to achieve and, hopefully, beat. So when you think about our EBIT guidance for 2014, we started the year at 65 [ph] basis points and delivered 76 basis poi
componenttext: So what I would say is that, when we put our outlook for the year, this is something that we expect to achieve and, hopefully, beat. So when you think about our EBIT guidance for 2014, we started the year at 65 [ph] basis points and delivered 76 basis points. So I would suggest that it's some level of conservatism. As I mentioned in my comments, we've got a prudent outlook -- prudent approach for our outlook for 2015, and the 80 to 100 basis point range is consistent with that.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a follow-up is, I think, you mentioned the Pro grew in line with the house. So I think, the past few quarters, it was a little stronger. So is that just a fourth quarter thing? Did you just so well around Black Friday with consumers that, t
componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up is, I think, you mentioned the Pro grew in line with the house. So I think, the past few quarters, it was a little stronger. So is that just a fourth quarter thing? Did you just so well around Black Friday with consumers that, that kept the consumer rate a little bit higher? Or was there something that changed on that side?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Robert. The Pro exceeding our overall business. But we had really good strong performance, which led to the strong comp we delivered in the fourth quarter, with great response from our retail consumer. I'll let Rick jump in and talk a little
componenttext: Yes. This is Robert. The Pro exceeding our overall business. But we had really good strong performance, which led to the strong comp we delivered in the fourth quarter, with great response from our retail consumer. I'll let Rick jump in and talk a little bit more detail about the 4% in the Pro.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. It was really the result of the holiday in the retail consumer. When you look at the Pro in general, we still saw strong demand across all regions with Pro. As a matter of fact, when you look at account growth, which is measured, then I look at deter
componenttext: Yes. It was really the result of the holiday in the retail consumer. When you look at the Pro in general, we still saw strong demand across all regions with Pro. As a matter of fact, when you look at account growth, which is measured, then I look at determined health of the Pros, still liability of the our process, programs, our Pro accounts grew 24% during the quarter. So still a huge take rate from Pros, as I look to leverage our benefit of our value proposition, as well as we continue to meet their needs. We did see positive comps across all ticket sizes and ticket ranges for the quarter as well. We show strength that we did not lose anything relative to any type of transaction size that we monitor or what you during that timeframe as well. So we feel good to Pro. We still feel good with the strength of the Pro and their response to our process and programs. And moving into 2015, we still think that we have room to continue their growth with the brands that we're launching in 2015, probably what we talked about during the AIC with GAF Group and Owens Corning, Lennox, [indiscernible] other brands that we're bringing back into the portfolio, as well as those brands we launched in the Q4. So we feel we do good for where we are today and in [indiscernible] of 2015 with relevance for the Pro.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

But in the fourth quarter, it was only 18 basis points. Is it really just that insurance issue? Was that The only factor that led you to come in below that rule of thumb? Or are there other things on the margins in particular to call out?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttext: So Mike, a bit of it was the impact of insurance. Some of it was the bonus payout that Rick mentioned going into the quarter. We expected a little bit more leverage in Q4 on the bonus line that we experienced, but we're happy to pay the associates on the strong results for the quarter [indiscernible]. The only piece I would mention, Mike, is the mix between, the 25 [ph] basis points mix impact hurt the flow-through as well.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: And actually, so if I could follow up on that. Two points. One, within the gross margin, you talked about price action. Can you give us more details there? And secondly, when you say less leverage on the bonus, I'm sure it's not that you expected a better
componenttext: And actually, so if I could follow up on that. Two points. One, within the gross margin, you talked about price action. Can you give us more details there? And secondly, when you say less leverage on the bonus, I'm sure it's not that you expected a better comp. It's just the payout was evidently higher. Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 2 things. The payout is based on our planned performance. So as we upped [ph] our outlook for Q4, it was a 7.3% [ph] comp. So we outdelivered our expectations by a greater degree going into Q4, which led to the increased bonus payout. As it relates to
componenttext: So 2 things. The payout is based on our planned performance. So as we upped [ph] our outlook for Q4, it was a 7.3% [ph] comp. So we outdelivered our expectations by a greater degree going into Q4, which led to the increased bonus payout. As it relates to your first question on price actions, really, it's tied back to Rick's comments on targeted promotions.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lasser with UBS Investment Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lasser with UBS Investment Bank.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to get a little bit more perspective on how you think your share is trending within the different bucket of ticket that we saw. Really good performance for your big-ticket bucket and slower performance from your smaller-ticket stuff. Does tha
componenttext: I was hoping to get a little bit more perspective on how you think your share is trending within the different bucket of ticket that we saw. Really good performance for your big-ticket bucket and slower performance from your smaller-ticket stuff. Does that -- is that any suggestion that as the consumer's reengaging with some of the bigger spend projects that the store location matters a little bit less, that you're picking up more of your fair share in that spending arena? And then conversely, is that potentially coming at the expense from the smaller-ticket stuff?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttext: Mike, I'll start and get Mike to jump in a little bit. I think, certainly, it's a lot of things we've been working on when we talk about the omnichannel differentiating own experiences. When you talk about the project nature of the business and the way we're focused on the project nature of the business, while we saw strong performance there is that we outlined [indiscernible] for kitchen and appliances, flooring, those types of things. And I think a lot of that is dovetailing with my comments earlier about consumer getting reengaged and some of those projects that, for lack better term, have been deferred in the middle of the downturn, as they're now getting more comfortable with the macroenvironment, getting more comfortable with their income, job outlook and more comfortable, quite frankly, that the value of their home is going to continue to move in the right direction. So a lot of teams we've been working on the past few years, setting ourselves up to take advantage of the macroenvironment that we find ourselves moving into now. I wish, I think, played itself out in the fourth quarter, and I think it's what's built into our guidance for 2015. So Mike, if you want to dovetail and talk about that?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttext: Absolutely, Robert. I'd add to it. headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael, that will be all the big-ticket discretionary categories. As Robert commented, the consumer view is feeling better about the situation, feeling better about reengaging with big-ticket categories but hasn't necessarily restarted in earnest. So if
componenttext: Michael, that will be all the big-ticket discretionary categories. As Robert commented, the consumer view is feeling better about the situation, feeling better about reengaging with big-ticket categories but hasn't necessarily restarted in earnest. So if you think about kitchens, flooring, millwork, all 3 of those categories, are the furthest away from where they were back in the peak.

componenttext: What I can tell you is as the peak goes on, it's where those categories were close to 19%, 20% of our sales. Today, they're 16% to 17%. So while all those have been rising, they're still lagging as a percent of the mix.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question is about the online business. I was wondering if you could give us a little bit more color on the performance. And maybe talk about, with such a large portion of sales from that business, pickup, in-store, are there any particular categories y
componenttext: My question is about the online business. I was wondering if you could give us a little bit more color on the performance. And maybe talk about, with such a large portion of sales from that business, pickup, in-store, are there any particular categories you see really driving overall sales?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jessica. This is Rick. I'll start, and then I'll let Mike jump in as well. We continue to be pleased with our performance at Lowe's.com. It was up 25% for the quarter, 2.5% of our total sales for the year. When you look at .com, the thing that we're
componenttext: Yes, Jessica. This is Rick. I'll start, and then I'll let Mike jump in as well. We continue to be pleased with our performance at Lowe's.com. It was up 25% for the quarter, 2.5% of our total sales for the year. When you look at .com, the thing that we're really working on is, as you said, we've been doing online, pickup, in-store for over a decade. So it's something that we really continue to focus on. Dennis Knowles and the team have done a phenomenal job on store operations and improving the experience of the front-end to make it easier for the customers to transact and get the products in and out of store quickly. And it continues to focus on our ability to drive our omnichannel aspects of what we're trying to accomplish and do it as an organization, increase that visibility across stores, .com, contact centers and all side or in the hold. It's a component of what we're really doing from an overall strategic standpoint. What we've been focused on over the last couple of quarters and in 2014 is really enhancing the experience that the customers have when they jump on our sites. So we've been working on delivery rescheduling. You've seen us work on improving our search capabilities and adding several thousand additional search terms to avoid getting back those no search results. We've improved our filtering of products. And we're also working on improving our content and improved content for 17,000 highly visible items on the site. So we're really looking holistically at the site to make sure that we continue to drive what we are working on. The thing that we're still extremely pleased with is that the store remains very relevant with the customer. In fact, almost 97%, 98% of all transactions still go through our stores. That's evidenced by the fact that we talk about 60% [ph] pickup, the other 10% delivered, and then a large portion of our personal orders are actually shipped from our stores. So they continue to play a critical role as we leverage that asset and continue to move forward in the future. Mike, I'll hand it over if there's anything you want to add.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would add that anything purchased online. So if consumer often starts online for inspiration, getting a better sense of how they can pull the project together [indiscernible] in-store experience, so that they can pick and work on the project. But applia
componenttext: I would add that anything purchased online. So if consumer often starts online for inspiration, getting a better sense of how they can pull the project together [indiscernible] in-store experience, so that they can pick and work on the project. But appliances, fashion fixtures, auto power tools are essentially means base for online. And we take an approach that for the consumer, they want us to be relevant whenever and wherever they want to interact with us. And so we recognize that [indiscernible]. We're also very careful to make sure that as we tie back our personalized approaches, that we're leaning into both what's important from a pricing perspective as well was what's important from a line perspective. As I said earlier, couple of Brent been added, in the kitchen lighting will feature online and our online to go over both ship it to the home, where [indiscernible] selections to our stores and see that [indiscernible] experience [indiscernible] online.

Those are the 2 main drivers of the -- [indiscernible] power equipment, so elevated generator sales in the quarter based on weather. As [indiscernible] 2015, we're modeling a lot of mixed bag going into 2015, but that [indiscernible] is a roughly 20-or-so [ph] basis point improvement that I mentioned.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my second question, your inventory was actually down out right year-on-year, which is a very strong performance, perhaps, even more than you're guiding for going forward. So is that a function of the strong Q4? And is the port a part of it
componenttext: Great. And then my second question, your inventory was actually down out right year-on-year, which is a very strong performance, perhaps, even more than you're guiding for going forward. So is that a function of the strong Q4? And is the port a part of it? It shows your outperforming your goal with no constraint to sales as a result.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll take a part of it, and then Rick will talk about the ports. As I mentioned, we're trying to kind of grow comps in the mid-single-digit, keeping inventories flat. A lot of effort and energy around improving the productivity of inventories. So that
componenttext: And I'll take a part of it, and then Rick will talk about the ports. As I mentioned, we're trying to kind of grow comps in the mid-single-digit, keeping inventories flat. A lot of effort and energy around improving the productivity of inventories. So that's just in Q4. The second is improved seasonal sell-through. I think with the seasonal goods are good quality product that we're sure carry over throughout the course of the year. We, in fact, did that in Q4 '13. Based on the strengthen of the seasonal step, the customer experience designed to so far better season sell-through Q4 '14 within '13. Therefore, we didn't have the carryover inventory.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Matt, I'll just add that we also account in-transit inventory on our numbers. So whether it's sitting at port over in our DC, just filling in our total inventory numbers. As it relates to our ports -- to the port issues, I'm extremely pleased wit
componenttext: Yes. And Matt, I'll just add that we also account in-transit inventory on our numbers. So whether it's sitting at port over in our DC, just filling in our total inventory numbers. As it relates to our ports -- to the port issues, I'm extremely pleased with the efforts of our supply chain in getting our products through to the port during this slowdown. As a matter of fact, we feel probably good and other than of our inventory heading into Spring. Currently, we have over 3 months of forecasted sales of seasonal products already in our distribution centers and in our stores. So we feel good from that perspective. We continue to monitor the process, in general, with the ports. And we continue to take steps to minimize any further impact such as moving product and cargo through other ports, rerouting the product to where we can get it to our stores the most quickly and time-effective means possible. But that teams have done a great job in flowing our product out of the port, getting the containers moved through. And really proud of what they were able to accomplish. So we feel good going into spring with our current inventory levels, and it's particularly against our forecasted expectations for the first 3 months.

componenttextpreview: So I thing there's a great debate out there on how much of the gas price declines will flow to the consumer, what categories are going to benefit and when. From where you sit, whether the consumer research or what you're seeing, is there a way to attribut
componenttext: So I thing there's a great debate out there on how much of the gas price declines will flow to the consumer, what categories are going to benefit and when. From where you sit, whether the consumer research or what you're seeing, is there a way to attribute any of the 4Q comp to -- in the industry growth, really broadly, to lower gas prices? And do you think that the lift is accelerating and still on the come? Or how would you frame that out?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Chris, as we think about drivers of our business, it's really 3 [ph]: households, employment and housing. So certainly, less dollars go towards fuel is going to be more discretionary dollars for the consumer to spend. So that's a fact. What we don't kn
componenttext: So Chris, as we think about drivers of our business, it's really 3 [ph]: households, employment and housing. So certainly, less dollars go towards fuel is going to be more discretionary dollars for the consumer to spend. So that's a fact. What we don't know is exactly how much of that's going to savings; how much of that's going to restaurants, vacations, et cetera; and how much is going to home improvement. So we know the customers got a little bit more walking around money. To your specific question, Chris, I can't determine -- we can't determine the specific impacts to our comp in the fourth quarter.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is there anything to say that, I guess, especially because you saw a lot of big-ticket durables. Is there anything to say that the benefit should actually accelerate? I mean, I think it's sort of general anesthesia to help all categories. Is there anythin
componenttext: Is there anything to say that, I guess, especially because you saw a lot of big-ticket durables. Is there anything to say that the benefit should actually accelerate? I mean, I think it's sort of general anesthesia to help all categories. Is there anything you're seeing or could say that, perhaps, that one fits believed to be sustainable out of consumer that over proven category would see a greater lift in the future?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Robert. Certainly, I think, as you listen to an economist speaker, they would say that the longer that we're going to go on, yes, the more that it becomes part of your discretionary income versus kind of a onetime impact. And so, yes. I thi
componenttext: Chris, this is Robert. Certainly, I think, as you listen to an economist speaker, they would say that the longer that we're going to go on, yes, the more that it becomes part of your discretionary income versus kind of a onetime impact. And so, yes. I think it's reasonable to assume the longer that goes on, the more likely consumers will spend a portion of that and more likely [indiscernible] one of their channels. So that's positive. We view that as a potential positive, as we think about our outlook for 2015. On the other hand, depending on how long it takes place, the impact it has almost in a slowing global economy, U.S. exports, multinationals, and the impact that can have on overall jobs and those types of things, don't lose sight of that, as it's -- it's not just a one-way street. There can be other impacts as well. We need to take them into consideration.

componenttextpreview: The only thing I would say, Peter, is that we're early into the process. If you recall, last year, we talked extensively about the outdoor living by experience and how we'd set in the great response that we saw from customers from an outdoor living. By th
componenttext: The only thing I would say, Peter, is that we're early into the process. If you recall, last year, we talked extensively about the outdoor living by experience and how we'd set in the great response that we saw from customers from an outdoor living. By the time we were setting out a majority of our stores, the deep South were already into spring. And so therefore, we didn't want to disrupt the spring selling season into deep South. looking back in the fall, you reset all of those. And so that's the earliest indication we would have to the deep South. And what we're seeing, and the receptivity from those consumers to what we've done with outdoor living experience has been very strong. So we're pleased with the early indications and just waiting for spring to get here for the rest of the country.

componenttext: So Aaron, when I take a look at relative profitability, [indiscernible] gross margin percentage [indiscernible] same as [indiscernible] operating expenses. As you think about operating expense opportunities, we do think there's a number of areas we talked about. So certainly, with some elevated bonus in '14, we'll plan to target Lowe's in '15 [ph], increase levers in store payroll, some advertising levers. Those are the big buckets. And the depreciating dollars absolutely fall in '15. So we have some healthy leverage there. Beyond that, the whole indirect spend category, we talked about it at the Analyst Conference in December. I talked about some discrete items in Q4, not because they were large drivers. I mentioned telecom and armored car. Specifically, this gives you a sense that it's real, and it's working. And we've got a number of categories in '15 that we're looking at things from store fixtures and displays, supplies [indiscernible] category in services. There's a variety of activity around that, where we think we can become a bunch more efficient going forward that will help improve the flow-through that we talked about, the 25 to 30 basis points.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Lowe's Companies Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Also, supplemental reference slides are available on Lowe's' Investor Relations website within the i
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Lowe's Companies Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Also, supplemental reference slides are available on Lowe's' Investor Relations website within the investor packet. While management will not be speaking directly to the slides, these slides are meant to facilitate your review of the company's results and to be used as a reference document following the call.
During this call, management will be using certain non-GAAP financial measures. The supplemental reference slides include information about these measures and a reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures.
Statements made during this call will include forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Management's expectations and opinions reflected in those statements are subject to risks, and the company can give no assurance that they will prove to be correct. These risks are described in the company's earnings release and in its filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Hosting today's conference will be Mr. Robert Niblock, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mr. Rick Damron, Chief Operating Officer; and Mr. Bob Hull, Chief Financial Officer.
I will now turn the program over to Mr. Niblock for opening remarks. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for your interest in Lowe's. I'm pleased that we delivered another strong quarter, with comparable sales growth of 7.3%. Comp growth was driven by a 4.9% increase in comp average ticket and a 2.3% increase in comp transactions. Th
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for your interest in Lowe's. I'm pleased that we delivered another strong quarter, with comparable sales growth of 7.3%. Comp growth was driven by a 4.9% increase in comp average ticket and a 2.3% increase in comp transactions. The mix of comp ticket and comp transactions was consistent with our expectations.
Comparable sales growth for our U.S. business was 7.4% for the quarter. We saw balanced performance across the country again this quarter, with all 3 divisions, the North, South and West, generating comps within a tight range. In fact, all 14 regions had comps greater than 5%.
Likewise, we reported positive comps in all 12 product categories, and our ProServices business continued its strong performance, with comp sales in line with the company average during the quarter. I'm also pleased to share that our team in Canada delivered double-digit comps in local currency for the seventh consecutive quarter.
We remain focused on improving our profitability even while investing in key capabilities to drive sales growth. For the quarter, we drove 115 basis points of operating margin expansion and earnings per share of $0.46, a 59% increase over last year's fourth quarter. For the year, we delivered comparable sales growth of 4.3% and earnings per share of $2.71, a 27% increase over fiscal 2013.
Delivering on our commitment to return excess cash to shareholders, in the quarter, we repurchased $1 billion of stock under our share repurchase program and paid $225 million in dividends. For the year, we repurchased $3.9 billion of stock and paid $822 million in dividends.
As we head into fiscal 2015, macroeconomic fundamentals are aligned for modestly stronger home improvement industry growth. Jobs, incomes, household financial conditions are expected to continue strengthening in 2015, building on the momentum gained in 2014. Coupled with an increase in revolving credit usage, these trends set the stage for higher discretionary consumer spending, and the sharp decline in energy prices should allow consumers to pump less money into their tanks and more into home improvement and other forms of discretionary spending.
Improvements in housing should persist in 2015 as well. Strong income gains, mortgage rates that remain historically low and moderating home price growth should keep home affordability at elevated levels and provide more support for home buying in 2015. Expected growth in the home improvement market is further supported by recent consumer confidence readings and the results of our fourth quarter consumer sentiment survey, which revealed that homeowners' views around personal finances and home values continue to improve. In fact, approximately 1/2 of homeowners now believe the value of their homes is increasing.
Along with the positive progression in sentiment, this quarter, even more homeowners indicated their home improvement spending was increased. And while most of the home improvement projects they have planned are still small ticket, the survey indicated a boost in plans for big-ticket projects versus this time last year.
In 2015, we will continue to focus on a few key priorities to capitalize on opportunities within an improving economy. We'll further pursue top line growth by differentiating ourself through [ph] better customer experiences and improving our product and service offerings for the Pro customer. In addition, we continue developing omni-channel capabilities as part of our long-term commitment to meet customers on their terms whenever and wherever they choose to engage with us.
We also remain committed to improving our productivity and profitability, with opportunities in a few specific areas, including store payroll, marketing and leveraging our scale to get cost savings on indirect spend. These efforts give us confidence in our business outlook for 2015. Bob will share these details in a few minutes.
But first, I would like to thank our more than 265,000 employees for their hard work and dedication. Their steadfast commitment to serving customers is critical to our success and an important driver of this quarter's strong results.
Thanks again for your interest. And with that, let me turn the call over to Rick.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Robert, and good morning, everyone. As Robert stated, we delivered strong performance in the quarter, and I'm pleased to share that our store employees earned a record payout from our sales and service employee incentive program. This program rewa
componenttext:
Thanks, Robert, and good morning, everyone. As Robert stated, we delivered strong performance in the quarter, and I'm pleased to share that our store employees earned a record payout from our sales and service employee incentive program. This program rewards store employees for achieving their sales and profitability targets and for delivering outstanding customer service. We continue to capitalize on an improving macro backdrop through our enhanced sales operations planning process, improving relevance with the Pro and expanding customer experience design capabilities.
In the fourth quarter, we used our enhanced Sales & Operations Planning process to coordinate inventory flows, advertising and training around our Celebrate the Season winter campaign. With this campaign, we targeted 4 important shopping occasions: Interior refresh, holiday decorating, gifting and getting organized. For each occasion, our store, logistics, merchandising and marketing teams collaborated to ensure that we had relevant products available to customers at the right time, that they were effectively advertised and strategically promoted to drive traffic and cross merchandise to build the basket.
As a result, we drove both online and in-store transactions and ticket growth, and we fulfilled orders in the most convenient manner for customer. Our ability to sell products from a store, online, in-home or through our contact centers is a distinct competitive advantage that [ph] allows us to engage customers on their terms [ph] whenever and wherever they choose.
We know that, for many projects, more than half of customers research online before making an in-store purchase. And for purchases made on lowes.com, approximately 60% are picked up in-store, 10% are delivered from the store and the remaining 30% are a partial shift. This speaks to our ability to leverage our existing infrastructure with the omni-channel capabilities we are introducing.
From a category standpoint, we drove above company average comps in flooring, kitchen, appliances, lumber, build materials, millwork and outdoor power equipment. We drove company average comps in fashion fixtures, tools and hardware.
Customers are increasingly interested in refreshing the interior and exterior of their homes, so we used targeted promotions, coupled with our investment in project specialists, to drive performance in fashion fixtures, flooring, kitchens, appliances and millwork. We are pleased with the project specialist programs. Currently, we have project specialists who focus on exterior of the home available across all U.S. stores.
Our interior project specialists program has an average ticket above $10,000, and customer satisfaction scores over 15 points higher than the industry standard. So we're expanding it to another 470 stores in 2015, reaching over 3/4 of our stores by year-end. With our ability to coordinate style, provide design expertise and find the right contractor to do the job, we are rapidly becoming the project authority of home improvement.
Within lumber and build materials, we spent -- we met strong unit demand for dimensional and treated lumber with robust inventory depth. We also leveraged our stores' canopy program, in which each market stacks [ph] the most relevant lumber and build materials to be stacked just outside of the Pro entrance under the canopy. This program helps Pros quickly find out inside [ph] lumber, plywood and wall [ph] board, quick out -- quickly check out, receive loading [ph] assistance and get back on the job. 
With outdoor power equipment, we met strong Midwest and Northeast demand for snow throwers. In tools and hardware, we saw a particular strength in power and pneumatic tools, we have a compelling assortment of national tool brands and we've expanded our relationship with Hitachi to include pneumatic tools. Combined with Bostitch, Lowe's now has the #1 and #2 brands, making us the destination for pneumatic tools, particularly for the Pro.
Kichler, the innovative leader in decorative lighting is another important brand for Pro customers. And I'm pleased to announce that we just recently added this leading brand for lighting assortment. The expanded relationships with brands like Hitachi and the additions of brands like Kichler build on a solid foundation to serve the Pro. In fact, 14 consecutive quarters of Pro comps at or above the company average are a testament to this foundation, which includes dedicated service in our stores, inventory depth and our 5 ways [ph] to save value proposition.
Additionally, bill-based [ph] Pro account executives and our national accounts team make it easy for medium- to large-sized companies and government entities to do business with us. We are also completing our beta test of LowesForPros.com, which has been well received by our pilot customers. This dedicated platform is fully transactional and will provide Pros usual functionality such as the ability to develop requisition lists and view the purchase history as well as customized product catalogs.
This site can also be integrated with purchasing systems Pros use to manage their business, further streamlining their day-to-day operations and help with them working more effectively. We have received positive feedback on the site's flexibility and ease of use and expect to make it available to all Pros this spring.
Last quarter, Mike told you about the holiday decor experience we implemented in all of our stores using the stage [ph] created for our outdoor living experience. This stage leverages our largest store format. Developed through a collaboration between our merchants, stores and customer experience design team, the holiday decor experience inspired customers to decorate, raise their awareness of the breadth of our holiday decor and gift offerings and provided solutions -- positive solutions relevant to the holiday macro season.
The customer response was very positive, and we improved sales, inventory sales group and gross margin for the products included in this set. We are now transitioning this space back to our outdoor living experience in preparation for the critical spring selling season.
In addition to our efforts to drive top line growth, we are focused on driving productivity and profitability. During the quarter, our stores once again effectively managed payroll hours as comp sales accelerated, increasing sales by hour by approximately 5% and driving 28 basis points of payroll expense leverage.
They drove this leverage while maintaining great customer satisfaction stores and best-in-class inventory shrink performance. We are pleased with the progress this year on sales growth, productivity and operating profitability, and we're committed to further improvement in 2015.
In 2015, we expect to drive sales growth as we further capitalize on the improving macro backdrop through increased relevance with the Pro, improved customer experiences and the continued development of omni-channel capabilities. We will increase gross margin by continuing to partner with our vendors to drive innovation and lower first [ph] cost by leveraging our supply chain fixed cost. We will continue to leverage payroll as we further align payroll hours to customer traffic and more efficiently complete noncustomer-facing task.
We will also drive expense productivity as we increase sales by reducing fixed expenses. For example, we will reduce our total marketing spend even while increasing our presence in targeted digital media. And we will obtain further expense efficiency by consolidating the procurement of [indiscernible] business services across our corporate in-store functions.
Likewise, we will increase inventory turns approximately 15 basis points, as we continue to hold the inventory per store flat while increasing comp sales. With solid depth of high-velocity items and job [indiscernible] in place, we will obtain additional inventory productivity as we continue to thoughtfully conduct our line review process.
We are excited about the further improvements we'll make to our business in 2015 and look forward to sharing our progress as the year unfolds. Thank you for interest in Lowe's, and I will now turn the call over to Bob.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Sales for the fourth quarter were $12.5 billion, which represented a 7.6% increase over last year's fourth quarter. Total average ticket increased by 4.9% to $66.17, and total transactions increased 2.5%.Comp sa
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Sales for the fourth quarter were $12.5 billion, which represented a 7.6% increase over last year's fourth quarter. Total average ticket increased by 4.9% to $66.17, and total transactions increased 2.5%.
Comp sales were 7.3% in the quarter. As you heard from Rick, further momentum from our initiatives and improving execution drove balanced performance in the quarter. Comp average ticket increased 4.9% and comp transactions increased 2.3%.
Looking at monthly trends. Comps were 6.7% in November, 7.2% in December and 8.2% in January. For the year, total sales were $56.2 billion, an increase of 5.3%, driven by a comp sales increase of 4.3%, a full year of portrait [ph] sales compared with a partial year following the August 2013 acquisition and new stores. For 2014, comp average ticket increased 2.4% and comp transactions increased 1.8%.
Gross margin for the fourth quarter was 34.6% of sales, which is roughly flat to last year. In the quarter, the mix of products sold negatively impacted gross margin by 25 basis points. Also, price actions hurt gross margin by approximately 10 basis points. These items were essentially offset by value improvement and better seasonal sell-through, which helped by 15 and 10 basis points, respectively. For the year, gross margin of 34.79% represented an increase of 20 basis points over 2013.
SG&A for Q4 was 25.24% of sales which leveraged 88 basis points. The SG&A leverage was driven by a variety of factors. In the quarter, store payroll leveraged 28 basis points due to better alignment of hours and customer traffic and strong comp sales. Property tax expense leveraged 21 basis points due to favorability in property valuations recognized this year.
At our analyst conference in December, we noted that expense productivity would come from utilizing our scale to reduce the spend on indirect goods and services. In the quarter, these efforts allowed us to leverage telecommunications and armored car expenses. Also, given the sales growth, we're able to leverage fixed costs. Lastly, we have approximately 30 basis points of expense leverage associated with last year's asset impairments.
These items were offset somewhat by employee interest deleverage of 30 basis points. The higher expenses were driven by both tire and rural [ph] vendor as well as cost inflation.
For the year, SG&A was 23.62% of sales and leveraged 46 basis points versus 2013. Depreciation expense was $362 million for the quarter, which was 2.89% of sales and leveraged 28 basis points. The leverage was driven by higher sales as well as assets becoming fully depreciated.
Earnings before interest and taxes for the quarter were 6.53% of sales, which represented a 115 basis point increase. For the year, EBITDA of 8.53% represented an increase of 76 basis points over 2013. Interest expense at $132 million for the quarter leveraged 5 basis points as a percentage of sales.
Pretax earnings for the quarter were 5.48% of sales. The effective tax rate for Q4 was 34.5%. The lower rate this quarter, relative to the 38.7% last year, was driven by tax provisions that had expired but were retroactively extended by Congress for calendar 2014 in the fourth quarter.
The tax rate for the quarter was also lower than our expected 36%, resulting in an EPS benefit of $0.01 per share. For the year, the effective tax rate is 36.9% compared to 37.8% for 2013. The lower tax rate for the year was the result of the settlement of prior year tax matters.
Q4 net earnings of $450 million increased 47% versus last year. Earnings per share of $0.46 for the quarter were up 59% to last year. For 2014, earnings per share of $2.71 were up 27% versus 2013. The earnings per share performance for both the fourth quarter and the year represent record highs for the company.
Transitioning to the balance sheet. Cash and cash equivalents at the end of the quarter were $466 million. Inventory of $8.9 billion was down $216 million or 2.4% from last year. The decrease was a result of better inventory management and improved sell-through of seasonal goods. Inventory turnover was 3.85, an increase of 11 basis points over last year. Asset turnover increased 10 basis points to 1.69.
Moving on to liabilities. Accounts payable at $5.1 billion was up $116 million or 2.3% to last year. The increase relates to an almost 2-day improvement in days payable outstanding. At the end of the fourth quarter, lease-adjusted debt-to-EBITDAR was 2.15. Return on invested capital increased 243 basis points to 13.9%.
Now looking at the statement of cash flows. Cash flow from operations was $4.9 billion, an increase of 20% over last year due to net earnings growth and working capital. Capital expenditures were $880 million, down 6% from last year. Free cash flow of $4 billion represented a 28% increase over 2013.
During the quarter, we repurchased 14.9 million shares for $1 billion through the open market. For the year, we repurchased almost 74 million shares for a total of $3.9 billion.
Looking ahead, I'd like to address several of the items detailed in Lowe's business outlook. As Robert noted, economic forecasts suggest modestly stronger growth in the home improvement industry in 2015. While we are optimistic about both the macro forecasts and our improving execution, we've taken a prudent approach to our 2015 outlook.
For the year, we expect total sales increase of approximately 4.5% to 5%, driven by a comp sales increase of 4% to 4.5% in the opening of 15 to 20 stores, which includes 6 [indiscernible] in 2 city center [ph] locations. We expect to report our highest comp in Q1. This is an important quarter for home improvement [indiscernible] compared to last year. While we expect the first half comp to be higher than the second half, we do expect that 2-year comps will improve sequentially through the year. 
We are anticipating an EBIT increase of 80 to 100 basis points. As I noted during our analyst investor conference in December, we are now targeting 25 to 30 basis points of the EBIT expansion per point of comp above 1%. While this is our expectation for the year, there will be some choppiness quarter-to-quarter.
For example, let me offer 2 items that will put pressure on the flow-through for the first quarter. In Q1 last year, we had 70 basis points of gross margin expansion, our strongest quarter of the year. This year, we expect gross margin to be flattish in Q1 while improving roughly 20 basis points for the year. Also, in Q1 last year, we had our lowest comp and therefore, reduced bonus accruals. This year, we plan to accrue to target levels, resulting in a deleverage of 25 basis points in Q1 while leveraging roughly 10 basis points for the year.
We expect that most of the EBIT improvement will come from SG&A. Expense leverage will come in store payroll, marketing, bonus and leveraging our scale to achieve cost savings on indirect spend. In addition, we expect a fixed cost leverage associated with sales growth.
The effective tax rate is expected to be 38.1%. A higher tax rate relative to 2014 is a result of the settlement of prior year tax matters recognized in Q1 2014. A higher tax rate impacts earnings by roughly $0.06 per share.
For the year, we expect earnings per share of approximately $3.29, which represents a 22.5% increase over 2014. We are forecasting cash flows from operations to be approximately $5 billion. Our capital plan for 2015 is approximately $1.2 billion. This results in estimated free cash flow of $3.8 billion for 2015.
We expect to issue incremental debt during the year as we manage to the 2.25x lease-adjusted debt-to-EBITDAR target. With approximately $2.4 billion remaining under share repurchase authorization at the end of the fiscal year, our guidance assumes approximately $3.8 billion in share repurchases for 2015. All future share repurchase authorizations are subject to board approval.
Regina, we are now ready for questions.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Alan Rifkin with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Alan Rifkin with Barclays.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Robert, maybe looking at the industry and your performance kind of from 30,000 feet, it suddenly seems that the macroenvironment is improving even if housing is okay, but not great. As you look at your business, do you think there's less cyclicality and i
componenttext: Robert, maybe looking at the industry and your performance kind of from 30,000 feet, it suddenly seems that the macroenvironment is improving even if housing is okay, but not great. As you look at your business, do you think there's less cyclicality and is it less tied to housing today than it has been in years past?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Alan, I think we've talked about this, something in the past and how -- really, when you look through all the prior cycles, when housing was -- turnover was going up and down, some of the values continue to maintain their -- comps continue to mainta
componenttext: Well, Alan, I think we've talked about this, something in the past and how -- really, when you look through all the prior cycles, when housing was -- turnover was going up and down, some of the values continue to maintain their -- comps continue to maintain their value and actually, there's a tinge of increase during a lot of those cycles. The -- but we saw that kind of disconnect in this most recent -- this most recent downturn when home prices dropped dramatically. So we're kind of going through this cycle. We're getting -- home price is starting to come back up. That's driving confidence among homeowners that they can reinvest in their home again. And certainly, there's been a lot of deferred investment, kind of the wish list, the to-do list on the refrigerator. So people are reengaging that. That's what we saw in our survey, where we're starting to see a slight increase in those that are not only taking the discretionary projects on, but also starting to move into larger projects because we're getting confidence in the macroenvironment, confidence in the value of their home. But at end of the day, income on housing are continuing to be the things that drive our business. So there was a little bit of a disconnect in the downturn, but we are seeing consumers reengage. And we feel good about that, what's built into our guidance for 2015.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one follow-up, if I may. With respect to foreign currency effects, what were the effects on your '14 numbers in aggregate? And what impact do you have built in, in your 2015 guidance as a result of the strengthening dollar?
componenttext: Okay. And one follow-up, if I may. With respect to foreign currency effects, what were the effects on your '14 numbers in aggregate? And what impact do you have built in, in your 2015 guidance as a result of the strengthening dollar?

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Alan, the impact was essentially nominal to us. Our international business, Canada and Mexico are relatively small pieces of our portfolio of businesses. We did have a modest drag on comps, 10-or-so basis points for the quarter and about the same for t
componenttext: So Alan, the impact was essentially nominal to us. Our international business, Canada and Mexico are relatively small pieces of our portfolio of businesses. We did have a modest drag on comps, 10-or-so basis points for the quarter and about the same for the year. As we think about FX going into '15 -- and this one, we've modeled roughly the same levels as where we are today.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttext: The question will come from the line of Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Lowe's Companies Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
